Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Modular Manufacturing - Democratizing Functional Materials Printing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will research and develop new functional materials for advanced additive manufacturing. The goal of this project is to develop high performance materials for light activated 3D printers. If successful, this will enable new tools for manufacturing and research. Applications of this project would enable affordable, waste-free, and energy-efficient manufacturing with the goal of lowering the barriers to innovation.


polySpectra has developed a new class of modular 3D printing resins, capable of manufacturing production quality parts with tailored geometry and chemical functionality in a single step. This process is called functional lithography - it unlocks the ability to simultaneously define the form and function of advanced materials. The application of functional lithography to additive manufacturing enables production-ready parts to be directly 3D-printed, whereas existing materials can only make prototypes, mock-ups or toys. The goal of this project is to discover and develop new materials using functional lithography, to push the limits of the materials that are available in additive manufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
polySpectra set ambitious goals for the Phase I project in order to rapidly achieve the technical and market requirements for commercialization. We have achieved almost all of our aims presented during our Phase I proposal in the past year. We successfully demonstrated that polySpectra’s functional lithography process, based on Photolithographic Olefin Metathesis Polymerization (PLOMP), enables direct additive manufacturing of high performance materials. Specifically, we have formulated cyclic olefin resins (CORs) as drop-in photopolymers for off-the-shelf stereolithographic 3D printers. We established that polySpectra’s CORs achieve thermo-mechanical properties that surpass all commercially available photopolymers today, specifically with regards to their tensile toughness and working temperature. The unmatched thermomechanical and chemical ?performance of CORs enables us to displace low-volume ?injection molding for many applications. In addition, we ?achieved our target print speeds, bill-of-materials costs, and resolution.

polySpectra successfully commercialized our first product, COR Alpha, based on the research and customer? discovery that we performed under this award. During conversations with hundreds of customers in many different application areas, we received tremendous ?excitement over the unique combination of toughness and high? working temperature that COR Alpha demonstrates. The broader impacts of this Phase I work include expanded access to advanced manufacturing, cost-competitive local additive manufacturing, creation of high-tech US jobs, low-carbon manufacturing, and dramatically lowered costs of innovation.


Last Modified: 12/01/2017
Modified by: Raymond A Weitekamp
